select_data_state.description: To explore the evolution of research on sensemaking, we should select relevant columns that might provide insights into the topic, such as 'Year', 'Title', 'Abstract', 'AuthorNames', and 'AuthorKeywords'. This will help us understand how the research on sensemaking has evolved over time, the focus of the papers, and the authors involved.
select_data_state.sql_query: SELECT "Year", "Title", "Abstract", "AuthorNames", "AuthorKeywords" FROM Papers WHERE "Abstract" LIKE '%sensemaking%' OR "AuthorKeywords" LIKE '%sensemaking%';

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and abstracts by year
years = df['Year'].unique()
keywords_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}
abstracts_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}

for _, row in df.iterrows():
    year = row['Year']
    keywords_by_year[year].extend(row['AuthorKeywords'].split(', '))
    abstracts_by_year[year].append(row['Abstract'])

# Analyze keyword trends
def analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items():
        most_common_keywords = Counter(keywords).most_common(3)
        print(f"Top 3 keywords in {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in most_common_keywords])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Analyze abstract trends
def analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, abstracts in abstracts_by_year.items():
        combined_abstracts = ' '.join(abstracts)
        most_common_words = Counter(combined_abstracts.split()).most_common(5)
        print(f"Top 5 words in abstracts in {year}: {', '.join([word for word, _ in most_common_words])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Plot keyword trends
def plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year):
    keyword_counts = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}
    all_keywords = set(kw for keywords in keywords_by_year.values() for kw in keywords)
    
    for keyword in all_keywords:
        counts = [keyword_counts[year].get(keyword, 0) for year in years]
        plt.plot(years, counts, label=keyword)
    
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
    plt.title('Keyword Trends Over Time')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Execute analysis
analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year)
analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year)
plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year)

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and abstracts by year
years = df['Year'].unique()
keywords_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}
abstracts_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}

for _, row in df.iterrows():
    year = row['Year']
    keywords_by_year[year].extend(row['AuthorKeywords'].split(', '))
    abstracts_by_year[year].append(row['Abstract'])

# Analyze keyword trends
def analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items():
        most_common_keywords = Counter(keywords).most_common(3)
        print(f"Top 3 keywords in {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in most_common_keywords])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Analyze abstract trends
def analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, abstracts in abstracts_by_year.items():
        combined_abstracts = ' '.join(abstracts)
        most_common_words = Counter(combined_abstracts.split()).most_common(5)
        print(f"Top 5 words in abstracts in {year}: {', '.join([word for word, _ in most_common_words])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Plot keyword trends
def plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year):
    keyword_counts = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}
    all_keywords = set(kw for keywords in keywords_by_year.values() for kw in keywords)
    
    for keyword in all_keywords:
        counts = [keyword_counts[year].get(keyword, 0) for year in years]
        plt.plot(years, counts, label=keyword)
    
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
    plt.title('Keyword Trends Over Time')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Execute analysis
analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year)
analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year)
plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year)

insights: The dataset shows a progression in the focus of research on sensemaking from 2010 to 2012. In 2010, the emphasis was on using social media for journalistic inquiry, highlighting the role of computational journalism and social media in sensemaking. By 2011, the focus shifted towards interaction with statistical models, emphasizing observation-level interactions and the integration of domain knowledge with data for insight generation. In 2012, the research further evolved to explore semantic interaction for sensemaking, focusing on user interaction and the integration of analytical reasoning with model steering. This indicates a trend towards more sophisticated and user-centered approaches in sensemaking research over the years.

question.question: How has the focus of research on sensemaking evolved over time based on the analysis of AuthorKeywords and Abstracts from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and abstracts by year
years = df['Year'].unique()
keywords_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}
abstracts_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}

for _, row in df.iterrows():
    year = row['Year']
    keywords_by_year[year].extend(row['AuthorKeywords'].split(', '))
    abstracts_by_year[year].append(row['Abstract'])

# Analyze keyword trends
def analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items():
        most_common_keywords = Counter(keywords).most_common(3)
        print(f"Top 3 keywords in {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in most_common_keywords])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Analyze abstract trends
def analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, abstracts in abstracts_by_year.items():
        combined_abstracts = ' '.join(abstracts)
        most_common_words = Counter(combined_abstracts.split()).most_common(5)
        print(f"Top 5 words in abstracts in {year}: {', '.join([word for word, _ in most_common_words])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Plot keyword trends
def plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year):
    keyword_counts = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}
    all_keywords = set(kw for keywords in keywords_by_year.values() for kw in keywords)
    
    for keyword in all_keywords:
        counts = [keyword_counts[year].get(keyword, 0) for year in years]
        plt.plot(years, counts, label=keyword)
    
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
    plt.title('Keyword Trends Over Time')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Execute analysis
analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year)
analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year)
plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year)

insights: The dataset shows a progression in the focus of research on sensemaking from 2010 to 2012. In 2010, the emphasis was on using social media for journalistic inquiry, highlighting the role of computational journalism and social media in sensemaking. By 2011, the focus shifted towards interaction with statistical models, emphasizing observation-level interactions and the integration of domain knowledge with data for insight generation. In 2012, the research further evolved to explore semantic interaction for sensemaking, focusing on user interaction and the integration of analytical reasoning with model steering. This indicates a trend towards more sophisticated and user-centered approaches in sensemaking research over the years.

follow_up_decision.reasoning: The follow-up question aims to delve deeper into the methodologies and techniques that have been highlighted in the research on sensemaking from 2010 to 2012. This builds upon the previous insights by focusing on the specific methods and techniques that have been emphasized in the evolution of sensemaking research. The current dataset, which includes AuthorKeywords and Abstracts, is sufficient to answer this question as it contains detailed information about the methodologies and techniques discussed in the papers. Therefore, there is no need to re-select data for this analysis.

question.question: How has the focus of research on sensemaking evolved over time based on the analysis of AuthorKeywords and Abstracts from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and abstracts by year
years = df['Year'].unique()
keywords_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}
abstracts_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}

for _, row in df.iterrows():
    year = row['Year']
    keywords_by_year[year].extend(row['AuthorKeywords'].split(', '))
    abstracts_by_year[year].append(row['Abstract'])

# Analyze keyword trends
def analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items():
        most_common_keywords = Counter(keywords).most_common(3)
        print(f"Top 3 keywords in {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in most_common_keywords])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Analyze abstract trends
def analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, abstracts in abstracts_by_year.items():
        combined_abstracts = ' '.join(abstracts)
        most_common_words = Counter(combined_abstracts.split()).most_common(5)
        print(f"Top 5 words in abstracts in {year}: {', '.join([word for word, _ in most_common_words])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Plot keyword trends
def plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year):
    keyword_counts = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}
    all_keywords = set(kw for keywords in keywords_by_year.values() for kw in keywords)
    
    for keyword in all_keywords:
        counts = [keyword_counts[year].get(keyword, 0) for year in years]
        plt.plot(years, counts, label=keyword)
    
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
    plt.title('Keyword Trends Over Time')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Execute analysis
analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year)
analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year)
plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year)

question.question: How have the contributions of different authors to sensemaking research evolved from 2010 to 2012, and what patterns can be observed in their collaborations based on the AuthorNames attribute?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Read the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Filter papers related to sensemaking
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False, na=False)]

# Extract authors and years
sensemaking_papers['Authors'] = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';')

# Count contributions by year
contributions_by_year = sensemaking_papers.explode('Authors').groupby(['Year', 'Authors']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Create a collaboration network
collaborations = sensemaking_papers['Authors'].apply(lambda x: list(zip(x, x[1:] + x[:1])))
collaboration_edges = [edge for sublist in collaborations for edge in sublist]

# Build the graph
G = nx.Graph()
G.add_edges_from(collaboration_edges)

# Plot the collaboration network
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 7))
nx.draw(G, with_labels=True, node_size=2000, node_color='lightblue', font_size=10, font_weight='bold')
plt.title('Collaboration Network of Authors (2010-2012)')
plt.show()

# Print facts
print("### Begin of facts")
print("Contributions by year:")
print(contributions_by_year)
print("\nMost common collaborations:")
print(Counter(collaboration_edges).most_common(5))
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the focus of research on sensemaking evolved over time based on the analysis of AuthorKeywords and Abstracts from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and abstracts by year
years = df['Year'].unique()
keywords_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}
abstracts_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}

for _, row in df.iterrows():
    year = row['Year']
    keywords_by_year[year].extend(row['AuthorKeywords'].split(', '))
    abstracts_by_year[year].append(row['Abstract'])

# Analyze keyword trends
def analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items():
        most_common_keywords = Counter(keywords).most_common(3)
        print(f"Top 3 keywords in {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in most_common_keywords])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Analyze abstract trends
def analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, abstracts in abstracts_by_year.items():
        combined_abstracts = ' '.join(abstracts)
        most_common_words = Counter(combined_abstracts.split()).most_common(5)
        print(f"Top 5 words in abstracts in {year}: {', '.join([word for word, _ in most_common_words])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Plot keyword trends
def plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year):
    keyword_counts = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}
    all_keywords = set(kw for keywords in keywords_by_year.values() for kw in keywords)
    
    for keyword in all_keywords:
        counts = [keyword_counts[year].get(keyword, 0) for year in years]
        plt.plot(years, counts, label=keyword)
    
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
    plt.title('Keyword Trends Over Time')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Execute analysis
analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year)
analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year)
plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year)

insights: The dataset shows a progression in the focus of research on sensemaking from 2010 to 2012. In 2010, the emphasis was on using social media for journalistic inquiry, highlighting the role of computational journalism and social media in sensemaking. By 2011, the focus shifted towards interaction with statistical models, emphasizing observation-level interactions and the integration of domain knowledge with data for insight generation. In 2012, the research further evolved to explore semantic interaction for sensemaking, focusing on user interaction and the integration of analytical reasoning with model steering. This indicates a trend towards more sophisticated and user-centered approaches in sensemaking research over the years.

question.question: How have the contributions of different authors to sensemaking research evolved from 2010 to 2012, and what patterns can be observed in their collaborations based on the AuthorNames attribute?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Read the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Filter papers related to sensemaking
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False, na=False)]

# Extract authors and years
sensemaking_papers['Authors'] = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';')

# Count contributions by year
contributions_by_year = sensemaking_papers.explode('Authors').groupby(['Year', 'Authors']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Create a collaboration network
collaborations = sensemaking_papers['Authors'].apply(lambda x: list(zip(x, x[1:] + x[:1])))
collaboration_edges = [edge for sublist in collaborations for edge in sublist]

# Build the graph
G = nx.Graph()
G.add_edges_from(collaboration_edges)

# Plot the collaboration network
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 7))
nx.draw(G, with_labels=True, node_size=2000, node_color='lightblue', font_size=10, font_weight='bold')
plt.title('Collaboration Network of Authors (2010-2012)')
plt.show()

# Print facts
print("### Begin of facts")
print("Contributions by year:")
print(contributions_by_year)
print("\nMost common collaborations:")
print(Counter(collaboration_edges).most_common(5))
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the focus of research on sensemaking evolved over time based on the analysis of AuthorKeywords and Abstracts from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and abstracts by year
years = df['Year'].unique()
keywords_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}
abstracts_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}

for _, row in df.iterrows():
    year = row['Year']
    keywords_by_year[year].extend(row['AuthorKeywords'].split(', '))
    abstracts_by_year[year].append(row['Abstract'])

# Analyze keyword trends
def analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items():
        most_common_keywords = Counter(keywords).most_common(3)
        print(f"Top 3 keywords in {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in most_common_keywords])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Analyze abstract trends
def analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, abstracts in abstracts_by_year.items():
        combined_abstracts = ' '.join(abstracts)
        most_common_words = Counter(combined_abstracts.split()).most_common(5)
        print(f"Top 5 words in abstracts in {year}: {', '.join([word for word, _ in most_common_words])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Plot keyword trends
def plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year):
    keyword_counts = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}
    all_keywords = set(kw for keywords in keywords_by_year.values() for kw in keywords)
    
    for keyword in all_keywords:
        counts = [keyword_counts[year].get(keyword, 0) for year in years]
        plt.plot(years, counts, label=keyword)
    
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
    plt.title('Keyword Trends Over Time')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Execute analysis
analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year)
analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year)
plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year)

insights: The dataset shows a progression in the focus of research on sensemaking from 2010 to 2012. In 2010, the emphasis was on using social media for journalistic inquiry, highlighting the role of computational journalism and social media in sensemaking. By 2011, the focus shifted towards interaction with statistical models, emphasizing observation-level interactions and the integration of domain knowledge with data for insight generation. In 2012, the research further evolved to explore semantic interaction for sensemaking, focusing on user interaction and the integration of analytical reasoning with model steering. This indicates a trend towards more sophisticated and user-centered approaches in sensemaking research over the years.

question.question: How have the contributions of different authors to sensemaking research evolved from 2010 to 2012, and what patterns can be observed in their collaborations based on the AuthorNames attribute?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Read the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Filter papers related to sensemaking
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False, na=False)]

# Extract authors and years
sensemaking_papers['Authors'] = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';')

# Count contributions by year
contributions_by_year = sensemaking_papers.explode('Authors').groupby(['Year', 'Authors']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Create a collaboration network
collaborations = sensemaking_papers['Authors'].apply(lambda x: list(zip(x, x[1:] + x[:1])))
collaboration_edges = [edge for sublist in collaborations for edge in sublist]

# Build the graph
G = nx.Graph()
G.add_edges_from(collaboration_edges)

# Plot the collaboration network
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 7))
nx.draw(G, with_labels=True, node_size=2000, node_color='lightblue', font_size=10, font_weight='bold')
plt.title('Collaboration Network of Authors (2010-2012)')
plt.show()

# Print facts
print("### Begin of facts")
print("Contributions by year:")
print(contributions_by_year)
print("\nMost common collaborations:")
print(Counter(collaboration_edges).most_common(5))
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the focus of research on sensemaking evolved over time based on the analysis of AuthorKeywords and Abstracts from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and abstracts by year
years = df['Year'].unique()
keywords_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}
abstracts_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}

for _, row in df.iterrows():
    year = row['Year']
    keywords_by_year[year].extend(row['AuthorKeywords'].split(', '))
    abstracts_by_year[year].append(row['Abstract'])

# Analyze keyword trends
def analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items():
        most_common_keywords = Counter(keywords).most_common(3)
        print(f"Top 3 keywords in {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in most_common_keywords])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Analyze abstract trends
def analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, abstracts in abstracts_by_year.items():
        combined_abstracts = ' '.join(abstracts)
        most_common_words = Counter(combined_abstracts.split()).most_common(5)
        print(f"Top 5 words in abstracts in {year}: {', '.join([word for word, _ in most_common_words])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Plot keyword trends
def plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year):
    keyword_counts = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}
    all_keywords = set(kw for keywords in keywords_by_year.values() for kw in keywords)
    
    for keyword in all_keywords:
        counts = [keyword_counts[year].get(keyword, 0) for year in years]
        plt.plot(years, counts, label=keyword)
    
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
    plt.title('Keyword Trends Over Time')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Execute analysis
analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year)
analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year)
plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year)

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Read the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Filter papers related to sensemaking
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False, na=False)]

# Extract authors and years
sensemaking_papers['Authors'] = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';')

# Count contributions by year
contributions_by_year = sensemaking_papers.explode('Authors').groupby(['Year', 'Authors']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Create a collaboration network
collaborations = sensemaking_papers['Authors'].apply(lambda x: list(zip(x, x[1:] + x[:1])))
collaboration_edges = [edge for sublist in collaborations for edge in sublist]

# Build the graph
G = nx.Graph()
G.add_edges_from(collaboration_edges)

# Plot the collaboration network
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 7))
nx.draw(G, with_labels=True, node_size=2000, node_color='lightblue', font_size=10, font_weight='bold')
plt.title('Collaboration Network of Authors (2010-2012)')
plt.show()

# Print facts
print("### Begin of facts")
print("Contributions by year:")
print(contributions_by_year)
print("\nMost common collaborations:")
print(Counter(collaboration_edges).most_common(5))
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the focus of research on sensemaking evolved over time based on the analysis of AuthorKeywords and Abstracts from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and abstracts by year
years = df['Year'].unique()
keywords_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}
abstracts_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}

for _, row in df.iterrows():
    year = row['Year']
    keywords_by_year[year].extend(row['AuthorKeywords'].split(', '))
    abstracts_by_year[year].append(row['Abstract'])

# Analyze keyword trends
def analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items():
        most_common_keywords = Counter(keywords).most_common(3)
        print(f"Top 3 keywords in {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in most_common_keywords])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Analyze abstract trends
def analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, abstracts in abstracts_by_year.items():
        combined_abstracts = ' '.join(abstracts)
        most_common_words = Counter(combined_abstracts.split()).most_common(5)
        print(f"Top 5 words in abstracts in {year}: {', '.join([word for word, _ in most_common_words])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Plot keyword trends
def plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year):
    keyword_counts = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}
    all_keywords = set(kw for keywords in keywords_by_year.values() for kw in keywords)
    
    for keyword in all_keywords:
        counts = [keyword_counts[year].get(keyword, 0) for year in years]
        plt.plot(years, counts, label=keyword)
    
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
    plt.title('Keyword Trends Over Time')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Execute analysis
analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year)
analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year)
plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year)

question.question: How have the contributions of different authors to sensemaking research evolved from 2010 to 2012, and what patterns can be observed in their collaborations based on the AuthorNames attribute?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Read the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Filter papers related to sensemaking
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False, na=False)]

# Extract authors and years
sensemaking_papers['Authors'] = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';')

# Count contributions by year
contributions_by_year = sensemaking_papers.explode('Authors').groupby(['Year', 'Authors']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Create a collaboration network
collaborations = sensemaking_papers['Authors'].apply(lambda x: list(zip(x, x[1:] + x[:1])))
collaboration_edges = [edge for sublist in collaborations for edge in sublist]

# Build the graph
G = nx.Graph()
G.add_edges_from(collaboration_edges)

# Plot the collaboration network
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 7))
nx.draw(G, with_labels=True, node_size=2000, node_color='lightblue', font_size=10, font_weight='bold')
plt.title('Collaboration Network of Authors (2010-2012)')
plt.show()

# Print facts
print("### Begin of facts")
print("Contributions by year:")
print(contributions_by_year)
print("\nMost common collaborations:")
print(Counter(collaboration_edges).most_common(5))
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the focus of research on sensemaking evolved over time based on the analysis of AuthorKeywords and Abstracts from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and abstracts by year
years = df['Year'].unique()
keywords_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}
abstracts_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}

for _, row in df.iterrows():
    year = row['Year']
    keywords_by_year[year].extend(row['AuthorKeywords'].split(', '))
    abstracts_by_year[year].append(row['Abstract'])

# Analyze keyword trends
def analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items():
        most_common_keywords = Counter(keywords).most_common(3)
        print(f"Top 3 keywords in {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in most_common_keywords])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Analyze abstract trends
def analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, abstracts in abstracts_by_year.items():
        combined_abstracts = ' '.join(abstracts)
        most_common_words = Counter(combined_abstracts.split()).most_common(5)
        print(f"Top 5 words in abstracts in {year}: {', '.join([word for word, _ in most_common_words])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Plot keyword trends
def plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year):
    keyword_counts = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}
    all_keywords = set(kw for keywords in keywords_by_year.values() for kw in keywords)
    
    for keyword in all_keywords:
        counts = [keyword_counts[year].get(keyword, 0) for year in years]
        plt.plot(years, counts, label=keyword)
    
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
    plt.title('Keyword Trends Over Time')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Execute analysis
analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year)
analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year)
plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year)

question.question: How have the contributions of different authors to sensemaking research evolved from 2010 to 2012, and what patterns can be observed in their collaborations based on the AuthorNames attribute?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Read the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Filter papers related to sensemaking
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False, na=False)]

# Extract authors and years
sensemaking_papers['Authors'] = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';')

# Count contributions by year
contributions_by_year = sensemaking_papers.explode('Authors').groupby(['Year', 'Authors']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Create a collaboration network
collaborations = sensemaking_papers['Authors'].apply(lambda x: list(zip(x, x[1:] + x[:1])))
collaboration_edges = [edge for sublist in collaborations for edge in sublist]

# Build the graph
G = nx.Graph()
G.add_edges_from(collaboration_edges)

# Plot the collaboration network
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 7))
nx.draw(G, with_labels=True, node_size=2000, node_color='lightblue', font_size=10, font_weight='bold')
plt.title('Collaboration Network of Authors (2010-2012)')
plt.show()

# Print facts
print("### Begin of facts")
print("Contributions by year:")
print(contributions_by_year)
print("\nMost common collaborations:")
print(Counter(collaboration_edges).most_common(5))
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the focus of research on sensemaking evolved over time based on the analysis of AuthorKeywords and Abstracts from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and abstracts by year
years = df['Year'].unique()
keywords_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}
abstracts_by_year = {year: [] for year in years}

for _, row in df.iterrows():
    year = row['Year']
    keywords_by_year[year].extend(row['AuthorKeywords'].split(', '))
    abstracts_by_year[year].append(row['Abstract'])

# Analyze keyword trends
def analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items():
        most_common_keywords = Counter(keywords).most_common(3)
        print(f"Top 3 keywords in {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in most_common_keywords])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Analyze abstract trends
def analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year):
    print("### Begin of facts")
    for year, abstracts in abstracts_by_year.items():
        combined_abstracts = ' '.join(abstracts)
        most_common_words = Counter(combined_abstracts.split()).most_common(5)
        print(f"Top 5 words in abstracts in {year}: {', '.join([word for word, _ in most_common_words])}")
    print("### End of facts")

# Plot keyword trends
def plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year):
    keyword_counts = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}
    all_keywords = set(kw for keywords in keywords_by_year.values() for kw in keywords)
    
    for keyword in all_keywords:
        counts = [keyword_counts[year].get(keyword, 0) for year in years]
        plt.plot(years, counts, label=keyword)
    
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
    plt.title('Keyword Trends Over Time')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Execute analysis
analyze_keywords_trends(keywords_by_year)
analyze_abstracts_trends(abstracts_by_year)
plot_keyword_trends(keywords_by_year)

In 2010, the emphasis was on using social media for journalistic inquiry, highlighting the role of computational journalism and social media in sensemaking. By 2011, the focus shifted towards interaction with statistical models, emphasizing observation-level interactions and the integration of domain knowledge with data for insight generation. question.question: How have the contributions of different authors to sensemaking research evolved from 2010 to 2012, and what patterns can be observed in their collaborations based on the AuthorNames attribute?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Read the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_024230/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Filter papers related to sensemaking
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False, na=False)]

# Extract authors and years
sensemaking_papers['Authors'] = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';')

# Count contributions by year
contributions_by_year = sensemaking_papers.explode('Authors').groupby(['Year', 'Authors']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Create a collaboration network
collaborations = sensemaking_papers['Authors'].apply(lambda x: list(zip(x, x[1:] + x[:1])))
collaboration_edges = [edge for sublist in collaborations for edge in sublist]

# Build the graph
G = nx.Graph()
G.add_edges_from(collaboration_edges)

# Plot the collaboration network
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 7))
nx.draw(G, with_labels=True, node_size=2000, node_color='lightblue', font_size=10, font_weight='bold')
plt.title('Collaboration Network of Authors (2010-2012)')
plt.show()

# Print facts
print("### Begin of facts")
print("Contributions by year:")
print(contributions_by_year)
print("\nMost common collaborations:")
print(Counter(collaboration_edges).most_common(5))
print("### End of facts")

import pandas as pd

# Filter papers by Alex Endert and Chris North
authors_of_interest = ['Alex Endert', 'Chris North']
filtered_df = df[df['AuthorNames'].apply(lambda x: any(author in x for author in authors_of_interest))]

# Filter by year range 2010 to 2012
filtered_df = filtered_df[(filtered_df['Year'] >= 2010) & (filtered_df['Year'] <= 2012)]

# Extract relevant information
contributions = filtered_df[['Year', 'Title', 'Abstract', 'AuthorNames']]

# Print the contributions
print("### Begin of facts")
for index, row in contributions.iterrows():
    print(f"Year: {row['Year']}")
    print(f"Title: {row['Title']}")
    print(f"Abstract: {row['Abstract'][:150]}...")  # Print first 150 characters of abstract for brevity
    print(f"Authors: {row['AuthorNames']}")
    print("---")
print("### End of facts")
